item.title: 305 – In the Days of No Work
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: In the Days of No Work i raged against the tomato plants that first day, raining and uncaring, raged against the vines rooted down in the raised beds, broke the stems the blood pulp on my hands first fruits turned back … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
In the Days of No Work

i raged
against the tomato plants
that first day, raining
and uncaring, raged
against the vines rooted down
in the raised beds, broke the stems
the blood pulp on my hands
first fruits turned back
swung the root-balls, dirt clods
a mace, cascading debris.
the rain came. the green zebras wept.
i built the pyre upon the bed
they’d slept in, left them their to rot
back down to tilth, in the dark to turn
to health. i raged the first day
and then washed my hands of them.
the rain came on. the rain came on.

item.title: 304 – Sewing on the Bus
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Sewing on the Bus A man’s yellow hand hangs above the black vinyl seats floats a moment then descends from view rises again & again: hovering a motion like grief. Such thin thread binds a white bone button to a blue shirt.
item.content:encoded:
Sewing on the Bus

A man’s yellow hand hangs
above the black
vinyl seats

floats a moment
then descends
from view

rises again
& again: hovering
a motion like grief.

Such thin thread binds
a white bone button
to a blue shirt.

item.title: 303 – Wvves
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Wvves What people want out of a poem (Mary O. said this the other day) is clarity of a thing unclear, pulled out and looked at plain. Tonight it’s dark and stormy and only looks to get worse. The poem becomes the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Wvves

What people want

out of a poem

(Mary O. said this

the other day)

is clarity of a thing

unclear, pulled out

and looked at plain.

Tonight it’s dark

and stormy

and only looks

to get worse.

The poem becomes

the wind and sting

of salt, the meaning

made in the moment

before the next wvve hits.

item.title: 302 – We fashion the tool to meet the end
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: We fashion the tool to meet the end and not, as the bower bird builds her lovely nest, a grave of accident: the child’s bright mitten chanced upon in the snow. The shovel lathed and left to stand at rest … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We fashion the tool to meet the end

and not, as the bower bird
builds her lovely nest,
a grave of accident:
the child’s bright mitten
chanced upon in the snow.

The shovel lathed
and left to stand
at rest in the cellar
until called to hand.
The bite of the blade
in frozen dirt.

Over the marbled yard made
of graven images, pale
petals scatter with the wind, left
to the bower bird
to line her lovely nest,
end to end.

(h/t Hans Jonas)

item.title: 301 – At This Difficult Time
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: At This Difficult Time I hate Enrique because he’s calm and unexceptional, like he’s helping me order pay-per-view or cell service. Who the hell up sells sympathy bouquets anyway? We’re nearly there when he bumps up to a lovely arrangement–roses, lilacs, the works– … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
At This Difficult Time

I hate Enrique because he’s calm
and unexceptional, like he’s helping me
order pay-per-view or cell service.
Who the hell up sells sympathy bouquets
anyway? We’re nearly there when he bumps up
to a lovely arrangement–roses, lilacs, the works–
and crystal vase for only twelve bucks more.
Who I am to haggle over a dead woman’s flowers?
It’s perfect, that linchpin of grief twisted just so
that you bleed a little extra, especially after
he so helpfully gave me the words for a card
I didn’t think I’d need: At this difficult time,
he softly intoned, we’re thinking of you. Sold.
I stuck to my guns and bid him down. Hooray.
Soon some woman out in Mill Plain
will receive an unexpected, econo-bouquet
from someone she didn’t know her mother knew.
I hope it’s lovely.

item.title: 300 – Cherub
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Cherub Enjoy those dollar food truck tacos and tortilla chips, ye rosebud cheek’d cherub. Linger in the dusky swarm of Anaheim’s slow prickle. Listen at the door to all the idle talk kicked down the avenue, the boys in their boots, the dogs … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Cherub

Enjoy those dollar food truck tacos and tortilla chips,
ye rosebud cheek’d cherub. Linger in the dusky swarm
of Anaheim’s slow prickle. Listen at the door
to all the idle talk kicked down the avenue, the boys
in their boots, the dogs circling, stood out at poles,
the busker canoodling his pickle tub a merengue.
Lift up your eyes, cherub, from the dirty cuffs
that pass by to the leaning marble of our Lady
of Truth and Sorrow keeping watch of the ragged lot,
patron saint of stone, weeping as the pigeons strut
and scramble for the broken crumbs of milled corn
falling from your lovely, fluttering hand.

item.title: 299 – Rail
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Rail A blued band of steel runs the wily wilded length of me, a flattened fist buried in dead leaves, amber bottles broken, sheafs of glossy women tossed aside. The haunts of lost men. No train runs this route, no howl at … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Rail

A blued band of steel
runs the wily wilded length
of me, a flattened fist
buried in dead leaves, amber
bottles broken, sheafs of glossy women
tossed aside. The haunts of lost men.
No train runs this route, no howl
at the midnight passing spooks
the fox in his den. Just wind
singing over steel, rustling clean
the spare and glinting truth
of a track lain long ago, forged, forgotten,
true down to its tang. A rail, singular
strength, a hum radiating up
from earth, down from the heavens
in a flash, in-set inception of bone
burnished to high shine, rigid,
righteous, free of dross. The rail
no man sets inside the chest, sits
ever-ready for the locomotive’s
second coming. Shake the dirt
at its passing. Rustle up the fox
as first witness to what has come
to pass at the spine of things,
new movement through the bracken
in the broken land.

item.title: 298 – Welcome
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Welcome you :are abstraction: pixelated repetition letter combinations that don’t exist yet :are magnetic: stirring in two bodies trying to knit yourself together :are the Keeper of the Keys: the heart’s 5th chamber at last unlocked at your cry :are not and are to come … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Welcome

you

:are abstraction: pixelated repetition

letter combinations that don’t exist

yet

:are magnetic: stirring in two bodies trying

to knit

yourself together

:are the Keeper of the Keys: the heart’s

5th chamber at last unlocked

at your cry

:are not and are

to come hurtling someday

into the world; welcome.

item.title: 297 – Mournful Bells
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Mournful Bells No shining path. No shovel or shelter-makings. Just the dark vee of geese plowing up the sky southward, their mournful bells clamoring late & lonely.
item.content:encoded:
Mournful Bells

No shining path.
No shovel or
shelter-makings.
Just the dark
vee of geese
plowing up the sky
southward,
their mournful bells
clamoring late & lonely.

item.title: 296 – Pass Through the Eye
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Pass Through the Eye Cut the camel up, fool. Strip off the hide, stuff it in the hollow hump. Pass the gory mess hand over hand through the Eye. Not easy, no. Never said easy. Never said impossible. Cut off … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Pass Through the Eye

Cut the camel up, fool.

Strip off the hide,
stuff it in the hollow hump.
Pass the gory mess hand over
hand through the Eye.

Not easy, no. Never said
easy. Never said impossible.

Cut off the ears of the rich man,
string them as coins on a cord
hung about the neck of the poor
man crawling through the Eye.

Hear the golden hallelujahs
on the other side. Crawl after.
